items.title: RegularPolygonMarker does not work if prefer_canvas=True
items.body:
Hello,

This is my first time using github, so I apologise if I make faux pas.

I am using folium version 0.11.0 within a Jupyter Notebook with Python 3.7.7. I have been getting to grips with the way in which the library is used, and learning about what works and what doesn't work with respect to plotting thousands of points and polylines. I have mostly been using ```CircleMarker``` objects for displaying my points because it looks like the ```GeoJsonMarker``` functionality is not yet merged into the master branch. I have also had some success with using ```BeautifyIcon``` for non-circular points.

Recently, however I have been trying to use ```RegularPolygonMarker``` to show points with different numbers of sides to represent different things and I have found that the resulting html contains javascript errors unless I set ```prefer_canvas=False```. My understanding, though, is that ```prefer_canvas=True``` is a good idea when showing a lot of objects.

**Example code**
The following is the code I have used, with ```prefer_canvas=True```, which leads to the problem:

```python
import folium
my_location = (51.5, -0.39)
m =  folium.Map(location = my_location,
               zoom_start = 12,
               prefer_canvas=True)

reg_marker = folium.features.RegularPolygonMarker(location=my_location, number_of_sides=4, radius=10)
m.add_child(reg_marker)

m.save("regular_polygon_test.html")
```

The marker does not appear in the resulting html map because, as far as I can tell, there is a javascript error caused by something in the file ```leaflet-dvf.markers.min.js```:

```
Uncaught TypeError: this._renderer._setPath is not a function
    at i._update (leaflet-dvf.markers.min.js:8)
    at i._reset (leaflet.js:5)
    at i.onAdd (leaflet.js:5)
    at i._layerAdd (leaflet.js:5)
    at i.whenReady (leaflet.js:5)
    at i.addLayer (leaflet.js:5)
    at i.addTo (leaflet.js:5)
    at regular_polygon_test.html:68
```

Is this a bug or just an issue with the leaflet-dvf library itself?

Thanks,

Mark.

```python3

I've tried changing the zip codes in my CSV file to have quotes around them, but that doesn't change anything.

Ideas?

items.title: Adjusting leaflet legend colors/values dynamically with python
items.body:
**Adjusting leaflet legend colors/values dynamically with python**

I am having trouble trying to dynamically adjust or set the legend for a folium map.  In the situation you have multiple layers that are constructed from the `macro` element.

[Here](https://github.com/mrcagney/examples_folium/blob/develop/notebooks/categorical_legend.ipynb) is an example of someone trying to inject the javascript of the legend dynamically 

The alternative is to use Javascript to lookup the elements and find the data within the geojson layer and compute the color and values and then do DOM manipulation of the legend elements through raw javascript.  Problem in that situation is that I don't know a nice way to lock in the DOM element ids for the generated python macro function and or how can I inject a specific javascript click type event that will reference the dynamically generated element ids.

Some pointers on how to build this out and or if there is a way to construct JavaScript event handlers attached to particular leaflet standard controls like LayerControl or Legend

items.title: Multiple GeoJsonPopup leads to Uncaught SyntaxError: Identifier 'name_getter' has already been declared

labels.name: bug
labels.description: An issue describing unexpected or malicious behaviour

items.body:
Hi,

Have been trying to use make an interactive map with multiple data layers using folium. And for each layer, I would like to have tooltip and popups. Therefore I created functions to generate popups and tooltips.

However, there are issues to create multiple popups for multiple layers.

I think the issue could be link to the "name_getter" in the folium class GeoJsonPopup(GeoJsonDetail).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9092165/83753969-80276b80-a66b-11ea-917b-b4ec1f6a6448.png)

as I got this error 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9092165/83754076-a8af6580-a66b-11ea-8dbe-00be320a9c23.png)

For GeoJsonTooltip, it works pretty fine.



```python
from folium.features import GeoJson, GeoJsonTooltip, GeoJsonPopup
def create_popup(field):
    popup = GeoJsonPopup(
    fields=[field],
    aliases=[field],
    localize=True,
    labels=True,
    style="background-color: yellow;",
    ),
    parse_html=True
    return popup

def create_tooltip(field):
    tooltip = GeoJsonTooltip(fields=[field],
                             aliases=[field],
                             localize=True,
                             sticky=False,
                             labels=True,
                             style="""
                                 background-color: #F0EFEF;
                                 border: 2px solid black;
                                 border-radius: 3px;
                                 box-shadow: 3px;
                             """,
                             max_width=800,
                             parse_html=True

                             )
    return tooltip

inwoner = GeoJson(
    geo_data,
    style_function=lambda x: {
        "fillColor": colormap_inwoner(x["properties"]["INWONER"])
        if x["properties"]["INWONER"] is not None
        else "transparent",
        "color": "black",
        "fillOpacity": 0.4,
    },
    name = "Resident",
    tooltip=create_tooltip("INWONER"),
    popup=create_popup("INWONER")
).add_to(nl_map)


household = GeoJson(
    geo_data,
    style_function=lambda x: {
        "fillColor": colormap_hh(x["properties"]["AANTAL_HH"])
        if x["properties"]["AANTAL_HH"] is not None
        else "transparent",
        "color": "black",
        "fillOpacity": 0.4,
    },
    name = "Household",
    tooltip=create_tooltip("AANTAL_HH"),
    popup=create_popup("AANTAL_HH")
).add_to(nl_map)
```

items.title: Basemaps not showing up by default
items.body:
Thank you for this package, I'm finding it useful :)

## Problem:
I am having a problem related to this, where I'd like to have 4 different options of base maps which aren't named in folium, and have one of them show by default when the map is loaded.

They all have ugly tile strings. If I load them all using `folium.TileLayer` (similar to [this issue](https://github.com/python-visualization/folium/issues/1189)), then there is no base map by default.

Is there any current way around this?

## How it might work?
It would be good if you could decide with TileLayer if the base map should be shown by default. The `show` attribute seems like the obvious choice. I would guess that it wouldn't cause problems for old versions of the code if it only worked if there wasn't already a base map which is going to be shown, but any way that it could work would be great.

items.title: Wrap the "Filter Leaflet Maps with a Slider" technique in folium
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

My (mostly marker-based) data sets contain many LayerControl layers but also have lots of points per layer that I would like to filter by a value range. The value range might be any scalar property of the data, but I'm only interested in doing this for one value at a time, **without altering the existing layers**.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

I found [this javascript "**Filter Leaflet Maps with a Slider**" solution](https://digital-geography.com/filter-leaflet-maps-slider/) but I really need to work in python and folium just wraps leaflet anyway so I don't expect adding this will be too difficult.

I don't have a strong preference about API details, but some way to create and bind the slider to a new kwargs property of fo.CircleMarker, fo.RegularPolygonMarker, etc. and filter before drawing would be great. I would expect the filter to apply to all layers equally. 

Naturally, as one moves the slider, the marker elements should be dynamically drawn and erased from the map as they are included or excluded from the filtered range.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

I've tried working with TimestampedGeoJson, treating the filtered values as time and selecting a spot on a timeline and changing the duration parameter, but in addition to that awkwardness that puts all the affected data points in the same layer. 

**Additional context**



**Implementation**

I can get by in python, but I'm not great. I'd need some examples of what it means to "wrap" leaflet.js to create usable and robust folium functions, and I really don't know javascript at all.

items.title: Draw plugin export button does not work in Microsoft Edge
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Draw plugin export button does not work in Microsoft Edge. When you mouse over the export button, Edge shows you the correct`data:` URL, but nothing happens when you click. No hints populating in the Developer Tools console or debugger.

**To Reproduce**
As far as I can tell, this bug happens in the base case.

```
import folium
from folium.plugins import Draw

m = folium.Map(
    location=[32, -109]
)

d = Draw(
    export=True
).add_to(m)

m.save('index.html')
```

**Expected behavior**
You should get the download prompt, as in other browsers.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - Browser: Microsoft Edge
 - Jupyter Notebook or html files? HTML
 - folium version: 0.10.1

**Additional context**
I think what's going on is related to [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33154646/data-uri-link-a-href-data-doesnt-work-in-microsoft-edge) SO issue. Edge doesn't allow `data:` URLs. See context from Mozilla [here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/Data_URIs).

This is the issue in draw.py
```
            {% if this.export %}
            document.getElementById('export').onclick = function(e) {
                var data = drawnItems.toGeoJSON();
                var convertedData = 'text/json;charset=utf-8,'
                    + encodeURIComponent(JSON.stringify(data));
                document.getElementById('export').setAttribute(
                    'href', 'data:' + convertedData                    <-----------
                );
                document.getElementById('export').setAttribute(
                    'download', {{ this.filename|tojson }}
                );
            }
```

From SO:

> The only solution is to link, using a scheme that is supported such as file:// or http://, to some resource that contains the content.

**Possible solutions**
Since the GEOJSON is generated by drawing, I'm not sure how you could link that to existing content using file:// or http://

folium is maintained by volunteers. Can you help making a fix for this issue?
If someone points me to the correct way in Edge, I will try.

items.title: GeoJson show arg doesn't work as expected

labels.name: bug
labels.description: An issue describing unexpected or malicious behaviour

items.body:
#### Please add a code sample or a nbviewer link, copy-pastable if possible

```python
def add_huc_chropleth(m, data_type='swe', show=False, huc_level='6', 
                      gis_path='gis', filter_str=''):
    
    huc_str = f'HUC{huc_level}'
    stat_type_dict = {'swe': 'Median', 'prec': 'Avg.'}
    stat_type = stat_type_dict.get(data_type, '')
    layer_name = f'{huc_str} % {stat_type} {data_type.upper()}'
   
    style_function = lambda x: style_chropleth(
        x, data_type=data_type, huc_level=huc_level, huc_filter=filter_str
    )
    if True:
        json_path = f'{STATIC_URL}/gis/HUC{huc_level}.geojson'
        folium.GeoJson(
            json_path,
            name=layer_name,
            embed=False,
            overlay=True,
            control=True,
            # smooth_factor=2.0,
            style_function=style_function,
            show=show,
            tooltip=folium.features.GeoJsonTooltip(
                ['Name', f'{data_type}_percent'],
                aliases=['Basin Name:', f'{layer_name}:'])
        ).add_to(m)

def style_chropleth(feature, data_type='swe', huc_level='2', huc_filter=''):
    huc_filter = str(huc_filter)
    huc_level = str(huc_level)
    colormap = get_colormap()
    stat_value = feature['properties'].get(f'{data_type}_percent', 'N/A')
    huc_id = str(feature['properties'].get(f'HUC{huc_level}', 'N/A'))
    if not stat_value == 'N/A':
        stat_value = float(stat_value)
    
    return {
        'fillOpacity': 
            0 if stat_value == 'N/A' or 
            not huc_id[:len(huc_filter)] == huc_filter else 
            0.75,
        'weight': 0,
        'fillColor': 
            '#00000000' if stat_value == 'N/A' or 
            not huc_id[:len(huc_filter)] == huc_filter else 
            colormap(stat_value)
    }
```
#### Problem description

Not sure if this is due to the loading of the ajax call to the geojson url or the fact it's so highly styled (would imagine the former), but the show arg doesn't get expected results when used as shown above. I monkey patched the folium.features.py file to have the GeoJson._template explicitly determine if the the geojson is added to the map or simply defined using the following snipet:

```python
 _template = Template(u"""
# ...
        {%- if this.show %}
            function {{ this.get_name() }}_add (data) {
                {{ this.get_name() }}.addData(data)
                    .addTo({{ this._parent.get_name() }});
            }
        {%- else %}
            function {{ this.get_name() }}_add (data) {
                {{ this.get_name() }}.addData(data);
            }
        {%- endif %}   
# ...
 """
...
# also need to add self.show to the init method:
def __init__(self, data, style_function=None, highlight_function=None,  # noqa
                 name=None, overlay=True, control=True, show=True,
                 smooth_factor=None, tooltip=None, embed=True):
        super(GeoJson, self).__init__(name=name, overlay=overlay,
                                      control=control, show=show)
        self._name = 'GeoJson'
        self.embed = embed
        self.show = show
# ...
```
#### Expected Output
Normally the layer inherited class takes care of removing the layer which was added by default by appending the geo_json_###...###.remove(); to the js script. My thought it that since the ajax call is loading it async it's finishing the .remove() before the layer is added and therefore all the layers are just turned on by default.

I'd be happy to make a pull request but I'm locked down on my computer and therefore cannot use your contribution workflow which requires installation of things. I submitted another basic pull request for a browser print plugin but again I couldn't follow the contribution work flow. Any suggestions on how I can contribute without using miniconda, etc.

'0.10.1'

i posted my issue here in the papermill repo first:

items.title: HeatMap doesn't use weights

labels.name: bug
labels.description: An issue describing unexpected or malicious behaviour

labels.name: work in progress
labels.description: Work is in progress on a PR, check the PR to see its status

items.body:
I spend quite some time tracking down this bug. I think it should be fixed or the limitation should be clearly stated in the docs. This is a major time waster and makes a bad impression on this otherwise great package.

This is a major bug coming for the upstream Leaflet.heat project.

- https://github.com/python-visualization/folium/issues/496
- https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet.heat/issues/43
- https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet.heat/issues/74

#### Problem description

The `plugins.HeatMap` states that the points used to create the heat map can
be weighted.

```
data (list of points of the form [lat, lng] or [lat, lng, weight])
```

However weights are simply ignored. This makes it useless for heatmaps that are based on a few points with different weights.


#### Expected Output

Weight should have impact. Or remove this option from the docs.

items.title: map does not render in jupyter with large numbers of points

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: The issue is a duplicate of a previous issue

items.body:
This is related to the comment by @bag189 [here](https://github.com/python-visualization/folium/issues/835#issuecomment-423871951).

I just ran into this myself, where in `jupyter lab`, my code execution completes, but the output cell stays empty. Using `m.save()`, the `html` output file opens fine directly in the browser.

```
$ pip freeze |grep folium
folium==0.10.1

$ pip freeze |grep jupyter
jupyter-client==5.3.4
jupyter-core==4.6.1
jupyterlab==1.2.4
jupyterlab-server==1.0.6

$ chromium --version
Chromium 79.0.3945.88 Arch Linux
```

Here is a reproducible example representative of my real-world case.

```
import folium
import pandas as pd
import random

n = 3100
df = pd.DataFrame({'lat': [random.uniform(25, 49) for _ in range(n)],
                   'lng': [random.uniform(-124, -67) for _ in range(n)]})

m = folium.Map(location=[39, -96], zoom_start=4)
for i, row in df.iterrows():
    p = folium.CircleMarker(
    location=[row.lat, row.lng],
    radius=3,
    stroke=False,
    fill=True,
    fill_color='#000000',
    fill_opacity=1)
    p.add_to(m)
m
```

Via guess and check, I found that `n = 3100` will render, but using `n = 3200` does not. I'm happy to open this with `jupyter` if you think the issue is on their side.

---

**edit:** I couldn't help myself. Looks like `n = 3167` is the limit (at least on my system) that will render, `n = 3168` will not.

In the `HeatmapWithTime` plugin, host `https://rawcdn.githack.com/pa7/heatmap.js/develop/plugins/leaflet-heatmap/leaflet-heatmap.js` ourself under a different name.

Search in the code base if there are other uses of JS libraries with the word 'heatmap' in them.

items.title: How does one [deep]copy a map object?
items.body:
I was hoping to cycle through a dataframe of `(lat, lon)` locations and add a big, opaque point for each, then a less opaque, smaller point. As I go, I want the small dots to stay to draw attention to each new point added.

I tried this without success (well, via `df.iterrows()` on my end, but here's a simper reproducible example):

```
bbox = [[44.935, -93.09], [44.955, -93.06]]
m = folium.Map(location=[np.mean([bbox[0][0], bbox[1][0]]), np.mean([bbox[0][1], bbox[1][1]])])
m.fit_bounds(bounds=bbox)

m1 = m
#m1 = folium.Map(location=[np.mean([bbox[0][0], bbox[1][0]]), np.mean([bbox[0][1], bbox[1][1]])])
#m1.fit_bounds(bounds=bbox)

folium.Circle(location=[44.95, -93.07], radius=50, fill=True, stroke=False, fill_opacity=0.8, fill_color='blue').add_to(m1)
IPython.display.display(m1)
time.sleep(2)
IPython.display.clear_output(wait=True)

folium.Circle(location=[44.95, -93.07], radius=20, fill=True, stroke=False, fill_opacity=0.3, fill_color='blue').add_to(m)
IPython.display.display(m)
time.sleep(2)
IPython.display.clear_output(wait=True)
```

I'm guessing `m1` is actually referencing `m` and is not really a copy. I tried `m1 = copy.deepcopy(m)` but get `TypeError: __new__() missing 1 required positional argument: 'source'`

Any suggestions? If I create the `m1` object explicitly using the commented lines above, it works, but this wouldn't work to create the desired effect of having existing translucent dots always there and only adding the new opaque dot on each iteration.

items.title: Archiving documents containing folium maps
items.body:
#### Problem description

I need to archive a Jupyter Notebook containing folium maps. Because technology changes and map tiles might move in 10 or 20 years, I would need to somehow save all the content into one file, which could be either XML, PDF or TIFF (or a mix of these). And I need to do this on a large scale, that means it should be some kind of batch processing doing the job.

#### Solution found so far

Some browsers allow headless printing, but the folium maps can easily be distorted and messed up inside Jupyter Notebooks. Furthermore, some map tiles are not fully loaded at the time of printing.

#### Question

Has anybody encountered a similar question? How can this be solved? I do not want to change the source code of the HTML/CSS/JS on my side as this might not be a stable and reliable solution.

#### Further sources
I tried to find answers at:

-  https://superuser.com/questions/1463819/print-fully-loaded-website-as-pdf-with-chrome-in-headless-mode
-  https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=986740#c3

but there has been no good answer so far.

items.title: [Draw Plugin] TypeError: document.getElementById(...) is null

labels.name: bug
labels.description: An issue describing unexpected or malicious behaviour

items.body:
#### Please add a code sample or a nbviewer link, copy-pastable if possible

```
import folium
from folium.plugins import Draw

m = folium.Map()
Draw().add_to(m)
m.save("map.html")

```
#### Problem description

When we use the Draw plugin with `export=False` it creates a javascript `TypeError: document.getElementById(...) is null`
As consequence of this, all the follow code added after we add the Draw plugin don't run. For instance, if we want to use the follow code:
```
import folium
from folium.plugins import Draw, LocateControl

m = folium.Map()
Draw().add_to(m)
LocateControl().add_to(m)
m.save("map.html")
```
LocateControl plugin will never be available because of the type error.  The issue is produce by this part of the code:

https://github.com/python-visualization/folium/blob/0767eb953a1062140f3db919feeb0bc82d853bd6/folium/plugins/draw.py#L71

As there is any element with `#export `ID, it breaks.

#### Expected Output

No javascript error.

#### Output of ``folium.__version__``
'0.9.1'

Provokes this `ValueError` to be raised, not only when `key_of_x` is `None` but also when `key_of_x == 0` (which I think is a perfectly valid value for a key):

items.title: Feedback for Tutorial
items.body:
Things to be Added to `folium` quickstart/tutorial:

- Seems like you need to get the location data from somewhere other than the map that is on the screen zoomed in.  Is this true?  If so, it might be helpful to give instructions on how to get the data from Google maps.

- It looks like all the iterations could be done within the initial cell to end with a final product.  It seems it could be helpful to explain the process of inserting a cell below to create separate examples that follow along with the tutorial.

- Click Control-Enter (after the m instance) is also something that I needed to know to have my map appear.

- Some exercises that may help a newbie:
  - How to change the image with the different types of maps available - seems there are different kinds available in folium
  - You wrote "The default tiles are set to OpenStreetMap, but Stamen Terrain, Stamen Toner, Mapbox Bright*, and Mapbox Control Room, and many others tiles are built in."
  - No image showed for Mapbox Bright - (turns out not all levels available)
  - No image showed for Mapbox Control Room
  - How to zoom in on the image with the different numbers.  For me, 16 was a better zoom that we had discovered during the Education Summit.  I tried it and my maps are zoomed in appropriately.  This may be obvious to a more experienced user or discovered by simply thinking about the zoom level command.
  - What colors are available for the list of markers and what other icons are available to put within the icon such as cloud and info sign?
